results.title: Awkward customers (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
John Cleese and Angharad Rees play two sales assistants who demonstrate how to handle awkward customers. Shows the customer in a temper, the compulsive talker and the rude, aggressive and offensive customer. John Barron, June Whitfield and George A. Cooper appear as the awkward customers. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: In two minds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
A basic training course for all staff who deal face to face with customers in any service industry. Shows how there is a danger of misunderstanding whenever two people begin a “sales conversation”. The problem is that the assistant does not know what the customer really needs and the customer does not know all the ways the assistant can meet these needs. Demonstrates with clarity and with humour that it is the assistant’s job to resolve both sets of uncertainty. Stars John Cleese. Narrated by Philip Bond.

results.title: More awkward customers (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Customer Relations in Practice”.
Emphasises the importance of professional knowledge of an organisation’s stocks or services in dealing with difficult customers. Highlights the customer who parades their knowledge, the silent customer who cannot communicate his needs and the finicky customer who requires every detail. Features John Cleese, Anghared Rees, Patricia Routledge, Bernard Cribbins and Lyn Redgrave. FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

group_works.title: The Mackenzie file
group_works.creator_credit: Ken Little, Open University and BBC-TV

results.title: The Mackenzie file
results.creator_credit: Ken Little, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Curriculum Design and Development”.
One of a series of a second level course from the Faculty of Educational Studies, Open University. A wide range of ideas and practices in education is examined with a view to discovering consistencies and inconsistencies. This is followed by a review of the principles involved in curriculum development. Ends with a survey of the various constraints on curriculum development and the forces which generate change.

results.title: Wind (A)
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
1857, The Australian Alps. Jess, a young black tracker and his elderly sergeant discover the body of a gold miner. They track the killer, an old Aboriginal man, to a cabin on a clear plateau. After losing their horse and with the sergeant in bad health they are forced to shelter in a cabin. As Jess falls asleep he is visited in his dreams by the old Aboriginal man. When Jess is faced with executing the old man he is forced to decide his fate, to choose his friend the sergeant, or to follow his ancestral soul. Cast includes Ralph Cotterill, Bradley Byqar and Steve Dodd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Harry's War (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, AFI [au] and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
